newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: PRESS DIGEST - S.Korean newspapers - March 6.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - S.Korean newspapers - March 6.

text.p: The following is a summary of major stories in leading South Korean newspapers, prepared by Reuters in Seoul. Reuters has not checked the stories and does not guarantee their accuracy. Telephone: (822) 727-5650. Fax: (822) 727-5666.

- President Kim Young-sam yesterday appointed Rep. Kang Kyong-shik of the ruling New Korea Party as new deputy prime minister and minister of finance and economy in a large-scale cabinet reshuffle that affected nine other ministerial posts.

- The ruling New Korea Party suffered from an electoral setback in the parliamentary by-elections in two constituencies yesterday. Opposition parties won the election in districts in Suwon and Inchon.

- Delegations from the United States, North Korea and South Korea gathered on Wednesday in a New York hotel room for a joint briefing on proposals for four-way peace talks, which would also involve China.

- The new economic ministers face an uphill battle. Numerous internal and external factors, including massive current account deficits, mounting foreign debt, plunging currency and the rising jobless rate, await the new team.
- Korea's foreign exchange reserves fell below $30 billion for the first time in 20 months as the current account deficit continued to widen.
